Award.AwardTitle: CS10K: Prioritizing & Expanding Access to Computer Science Instruction in High-needs High Schools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Teach For America (TFA) proposes to recruit and support a diverse group of teachers to teach computer science (CS) in high-needs public high schools. Often students at low-resourced schools--frequently low-income students and students of color--do not receive the high-quality, rigorous computer science instruction needed for success in college and beyond. This CS10K proposal aims to increase access to CS for students of color, low-income students, female students, and students with intersections of these identities. TFA is well positioned to accomplish this as its organizational vision focuses on improving educational opportunities for all children, particularly low-income children and children of color. TFA placement schools serve students historically underrepresented in computing by socioeconomic status (>80% eligible for free/reduced price lunch) and racial/ethnic backgrounds (>80% identify as African American or Latino/a).

The proposed work will implement the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) course in urban and rural public high schools in 10 Teach For America (TFA) regions over the next three years, beginning with New York City, South Carolina, Kansas City, and the Rio Grande Valley. Specifically, TFA proposes to prepare 83 teachers, designated as ECS Fellows for at least a three-year period. In their first year as ECS Fellows, participating teachers will advocate for CS instruction in their schools. In their second and third years, they will teach the ECS curriculum, and in their third year and beyond, they will have the opportunity to become ECS Professional Development Facilitators. The long-term outcomes of this project are three-fold: more students in high needs areas will have access to ECS; a talent pipeline of CS10K educators will be created to serve high-needs populations, become advocates for increased access to CS, and prepare future ECS teachers in high-needs communities; and school leaders in high-needs high schools will commit to broadening participation in CS activities. This CS10K proposal plans to directly address existing CS education inequities and expands the research base in the following ways:

-- Recruit diverse leaders to teach CS in high-needs public high schools
-- Partner with school and district leaders to ensure high-needs high schools prioritize ECS in their course offerings and provide them with teachers who are qualified to teach ECS
-- Work with the ECS team to prepare and support 83 ECS Fellows to deliver the ECS curriculum to nearly 2,000 9th-12th grade students in high-needs urban and rural high schools

In evaluating this work, TFA will partner with SRI International to conduct a rigorous evaluation to answer the following questions of interest to both TFA and the broader CS education field: What is the impact of this project on CS learning and broadening participation in CS among students participating in the ECS courses led by ECS Fellows? What are the impacts of this project on teacher capacity and teacher leadership in CS? What are administrators? views on offering CS? How do they prioritize CS and navigate barriers?

POR.DRECONTENT:
With support from the National Science Foundation, Teach for America (TFA) led a three-year initiative titled CS10K: Prioritizing & Expanding Access to Computer Science Instruction in High-needs High Schools. The project worked to establish administrator commitments to offering computer science (CS) courses in high-needs high schools in 10 regions across the US and prepared and supported high school teachers offering the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) curriculum and serving as champions for computer science in their schools and communities.

Broader Impacts
Through summer professional development and an online professional learning community, three cohorts of teacher fellows totaling 70 teachers over four years were prepared to teach the Exploring Computer Science course in their schools and serve as champions for computer science within their schools and communities through a summer institute and ongoing online professional supports. During the project, the Exploring Computer Science course was offered in 42 participating schools, resulting in approximately 600 students taking the course in schools where it had not previously been offered. 

Intellectual Merit
As the external evaluator, SRI International studied progress toward the project?s three goals of (1) securing commitments to offer CS experiences from school leaders; (2) preparing teachers to teach CS and serve as champions for computer science at their schools, and (3) providing students with opportunities for further CS study. 

Through surveys and interviews, teachers reported that they were confident and well prepared by the project professional development to offer the ECS course in their schools and serve as champions for CS experiences outside of class time. A large number of teachers who participated in the professional development were then unable to teach the course for a variety of reasons - most commonly because they were needed to teach core subjects. In some schools, ECS Fellows found it challenging to recruit a class group that mirrored the demographics of the school for an elective CS course. Teachers who did offer the ECS course reported that they had adequate support and resources to provide CS learning experiences for their students.

As the Computer Science for All movement continues to gather steam, the findings from this project offer important insights into the challenges of scaling access to CS in high-needs schools and into teacher-oriented approaches to expanding access to CS instruction. While teachers can be powerful advocates, lasting systemic changes are difficult to achieve without institutional supports. Out-of-school time exposure to CS may offer an alternative in cases where ECS does not get onto the schedule. Local conditions that can work against course adoption include individual biases, lack of teacher capacity in core subjects, and a packed schedule of required courses. These evaluation findings are relevant to questions in the field of computer science education concerning the viability of teacher-oriented approaches to broadening access to CS.

 


Last Modified: 08/16/2019
Modified by: Ruthie Ousley
